item.title: Father's Day: what does being a dad mean to you?
item.trailText: To celebrate Father’s Day this Sunday in the UK and US, we’d like to see your photos and experiences of fatherhood
item.standFirst: To celebrate Father’s Day this Sunday in the UK and US, we’d like to see your photos and experiences of fatherhood
item.body:
With Father’s Day coming up this Sunday 21 June, we’d like you to share your stories, videos and photographs of fatherhood. Whether you’ve recently become a father for the first time, or have seen your children grow up and have families of their own, we’d like to hear your stories.

Father’s Day is also a time to remember your own fathers, so if you have a photograph or story about them, share it with us. We will feature the most interesting contributions in a Father’s Day gallery.

Some of you have already shared photographs of history repeating itself with your own children becoming fathers themselves:

Others have shared their most treasured memories of their own fathers and how they became doting grandparents:

Whether you have an experience of fatherhood or a photograph and story about your own father, you can share your photos, videos and stories by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments.’

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.

cards.title: Restoring balance / These are nation-changing times — help us hold power to account
cards.rawTitle: These are nation-changing times — help us hold power to account

item.title: These are nation-changing times — help us hold power to account
item.trailText: In a tipped-up, one-sided media, the Guardian is here to restore balance. Become a Guardian Member and join our community of writers and readers to debate the big issues and help us challenge the status quo
item.standFirst: In a tipped-up, one-sided media, the Guardian is here to restore balance. Become a Guardian Member and join our community of writers and readers to debate the big issues and help us challenge the status quo
item.body:
After the election, with five years until the next, there is more need than ever for a strong, independent voice to stand out against the prevailing winds. Ahead of us lie decisions that may change the nature of Britain irrevocably – and it is essential that there are journalists who are asking tough questions and challenging the status quo.

With the Human Rights Act in jeopardy, the Guardian will be there exposing the myth-makers. When the home secretary herself repeats media distortions about human rights – “The illegal immigrant who cannot be deported because, and I am not making this up, he had a pet cat” – someone needs to set the record straight: no, minister, the judge did not say the cat stopped the man’s deportation.

When severe benefit cuts fall on those least able to cope, the Guardian will make sure the impact is revealed. When the public is told that Benefits Street-type scroungers take the lion’s share, the Guardian strips the factoids from the facts: only 3% of the social security bill goes to the unemployed, while half goes to pensioners. When the bedroom tax and benefit sanctions leave families without food, the Guardian shines a light on the plight of those using food banks.

If you read the Guardian, become a Member and part of our community of writers and readers

Britain faces a monumental decision in the EU referendum. However strict the rules for the yes and no campaigns, nothing will stop the blasts from Britain’s Eurosceptic media. A wall of sound will warp the democratic process – and the Guardian’s independent voice will matter more than ever. No press baron owns us, so we are free to think, write and report without constraint.

I doubt anyone agrees with everything we publish, and indeed we make a point of encouraging a rainbow of views from contributors. But in a tipped-up, one-sided media, the Guardian is here to restore balance, hold power to account, challenge the conventional view and give a voice to the voiceless.

If you read the Guardian, become a Member and part of our community of writers and readers. Stand with us at live events to get closer to the issues of these times. Bring us your stories and contribute your thoughts.

These are crucial nation-changing years so, above all, become a Member to help support fearless, independent journalism, open to all readers, with no paywall.

item.title: International Yoga Day: share your photos, videos and stories
item.trailText: Whether you’re a yoga enthusiast or trying it for the first time, we’d like to see your pictures and hear your experiences
item.standFirst: Whether you’re a yoga enthusiast or trying it for the first time, we’d like to see your pictures and hear your experiences
item.body:
The first International Yoga Day is set to take place on Sunday 21 June, with 35,000 people gathering in New Delhi in an attempt to break the world record for the largest yoga class. If you’re planning on celebrating the day we’d like to hear from you.

Will you be attending one of the free sessions taking place around the world, like the ones in London or Salzburg? What’s your favourite yoga pose? Whether it’s a picture of your best downward dog or you’re trying it for the first time, share your photos, videos and stories with us.

You can do this by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments.’

item.title: Ramadan: share your photos and stories
item.trailText: How are you preparing for the ninth month of the Islamic calendar? Share your experiences and pictures with us
item.standFirst: How are you preparing for the ninth month of the Islamic calendar? Share your experiences and pictures with us
item.body:
Ramadan, the holiest month in the Islamic calendar, begins this evening with Muslims around the world fasting for a month from sunrise until sunset.

During Ramadan, as well as fasting many Muslims give money or volunteer for particular causes. What are you doing for Ramadan? Are you fasting, fundraising or helping the homeless? Have you set yourself a particular challenge or are you doing something different this year? We’d also like to hear from those adhering to traditions in modern or unusual surroundings, such as the Somalis marking Ramadan in a synagogue in north London.

You can share your photos, videos and stories by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments.’

item.title: Books about Honolulu: readers' picks
item.trailText: The Hawaiian state capital offers literary gems galore. Whether you’re heading there or just want to add some tropical flair to your library, here are our readers’ recommendations
item.standFirst:
The Hawaiian state capital offers literary gems galore. Whether you’re heading there or just want to add some tropical flair to your library, here are our readers’ recommendations

  • Anisse Gross introduces the literature of Honolulu
item.body:
An American city that doesn’t think of itself as American; a port that connects the United States to the Pacific and beyond; a travellers’ playground where Mark Twain took up surfing ... Honolulu’s literature is as various as its chequered past, as Anisse Gross explained in our blog last week. But the list keeps growing. Guardian readers had a lot to add, and here are some of their excellent suggestions. Let it be noted that some of the books, while being partly set in or about Honolulu, revolve around locations in all of the Hawaiian islands. Dive in ...

1. Paradise News by David Lodge (1991)

Readers Nicola Melody and Kathleen Ricker recommended this “bitingly funny” book by the British author David Lodge:

[...] about a defrocked priest, on a mission to visit his dying aunt in Honolulu, who, in an attempt to economize, ends up booking a package tour with a ridiculous cohort of fellow travellers. Shades of Waugh.

Nigel Sheldon added:

Although definitely not among Lodge’s best (a quick nod to Nice Work and Thinks) it is still a deeply engaging, sometimes sad, sometimes hilarious commentary on mass tourism in general (and Hawaii in particular) as well as on the politics of religious doubt. And by the way: do read this one on a long plane trip ...

From the book:

[…] it’s also one of the most isolated places on earth,” I said, remembering the lights of Honolulu suddenly appearing out of the black abyss of the Pacific night. “That’s what makes it a rather mythical place, in spite of all the crowds and commercialism.”

Sheldrake pricked up his ears at the word “mythical”.

I asked him if it wouldn’t be simpler to look up the Honolulu telephone directory under “Paradise”, and he seemed rather offended. “That’s not the way we do fieldwork,” he said.

There was, after all, something incongruous, even indecent, about using a package holiday to visit a dying relative.

2. The Descendants by Kaui Hart Hemmings (2007)

“Forget the film with George Clooney,” says DirtyDingo. “This is a seriously good book. And contemporary.” So we will put aside the – also excellent – film starring George Clooney, and delve into this tragicomic novel about family and loss, which tells the story of a man, a wealthy landowner and descendant of Hawaiian royalty, whose wife falls into a coma after a boat-racing accident.

From the book:

I bet in big cities you can walk down the street scowling and no one will ask you what’s wrong or encourage you to smile, but everyone here has the attitude that we’re lucky to live in Hawaii; paradise reigns supreme. I think paradise can go fuck itself.

3. From Here to Eternity by James Jones (1951)

This classic novel follows a group of soldiers stationed at Honolulu’s Schofield Barracks shortly before the Pearl Harbor attack. The book won the National Book Award in the US and is considered one of the best American novels of the last century. It was originally published without the four-letter words and descriptions of gay sex that have now been restored by Jones’s heirs. Recommended by sotac27.

From the book:

Sitting on the porch alone, listening to them fixing supper, he felt again the indignation he had felt before, the sense of loss and the aloneness, the utter defenselessness that was each man’s lot, sealed up in his bee cell from all the others in the world. But the smelling of boiling vegetables and pork reached him from the inside, the aloneness left him for a while. The warm moist smell promised other people lived and were preparing supper.

4. Democracy by Joan Didion (1984)

This novel, set between Hawaii and south-east Asia at the end of the Vietnam war, tells the story of the wife of a US senator and her romance with a CIA agent and racketeer. “A modern classic and criminally under-read,” said goldennuggets. It has been praised for its political vision as well as for Didion’s original style, “more suited to New Journalism than fiction”, according to Kirkus Reviews, in which the narrator identifies herself as Didion (“Call me the author”) and plays numerous tricks on the reader.

From the book:

Objects (3) and (4): two faded Kodacolor snapshots, taken by me, both showing broken rainbows on the lawn of the house I was renting in Honolulu the year I began making notes about this situation.

5. Sleeping Beauties by Susannah Moore (1993)

As writing set in Hawaii goes, this novel “is unparalleled”, said mignonnette, who also recommended Light Years and Whiteness of Bones by the same author. “It’s lush in the non-Gavin and Stacey sense of the word.” This novel tells the story of Clio, a 13-year-old runaway who, after a dysfunctional childhood, moves in with a family member who teaches her the legends and rites of Hawaii. As in her other books, Moore’s novel has a backdrop of Hawaiian beauty and tradition, with a young woman’s voice as protagonist.

6. Hawaii’s Story by Hawaii’s Queen by Liliʻuokalani (1898)

The last monarch of the Kingdom of Hawai‘i gives her account of the island’s fall and its annexation by the US in 1898. Queen Liliʻuokalani tells the story of her childhood, her reign and the revolution that left her imprisoned in Iolani Palace.

From the book:

Strangers have remarked that in no part of the world visited by them have they found the rules of etiquette so exactly laid down and so persistently observed as in Honolulu, when the Islands were under the monarchy. It is to be expected, therefore, that I know what is due to me; that further, as the wife of the governor of Oahu, as the princess royal, and as the reigning sovereign, it was not necessary for me to take lessons in the departments of social or diplomatic etiquette before residing in the national capital of the United States, or making and receiving visits of any nature.

7. Born in Paradise (1940) and other works by Armine von Tempski

Mostly set in the island of Maui, von Tempski’s novel gives a unique perspective on Hawaii at the beginning of the 20th century. Her early life surrounded by rich pastures and Hawaiian cowboys (or paniolos) is brought to life through the eyes of a child. Beth Bradshaw said:

I’d add the books of noted author Armine von Tempski, who spent her childhood on the family ranch in Haleakala. Her novels, some semi-autobiographical, beginning with Born in Paradise, published first in 1940, depict a time gone by. In print and worth checking out for a lazy summer read. (She also did a trio of young adult books, best known among them Bright Spurs, about the struggles of two young sisters converting their late parent’s cattle ranch into a guest resort).

Extra notes: a list of excellent local writers

Reader ID7477643, who was born and raised in Hawaii, shared the following list of local writers who have written about the island:

Reading a book about Hawaii, or Honolulu, written by a local gives the reader a different perspective about a culture that is often represented by its “tourist culture”, for good or bad. So, to that end, I’d like to suggest some local writers who have written about Hawaii, have books that take place in Honolulu, and have deep and meaningful connections with Hawaii.

This list is not comprehensive by any means – just a list of writers whose work is pretty accessible and pretty wonderful: Kaui Hart Hemmings (mentioned already), Lois-Ann Yamanaka (poet and novelist), Juliet Kono (poet and novelist), Lee Cataluna (novelist), Cathy Song (poet), Darry Lum (novelist), R Zamora Linmark (novelist), Brenda Kwon (novelist), Sylvia Watanabe (novelist), Eric Chock (poet).
